summary: This is a supplemental pretrial motion memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team in the Southern District of New York. The motion argues that the S2 Superseding Indictment should be dismissed or limited because the charges (Counts One, Three, Five, and Six) are barred by the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein, violate double jeopardy, are time-barred, and are multiplicitous. It focuses heavily on the allegations of 'Accuser-4' (Minor Victim-4), arguing her recent accusations against Maxwell are inconsistent with her 2007-2008 statements to the Florida investigation which implicated Sarah Kellen, not Maxwell.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, filing motions to dismiss the S2 Superseding Indictment. Her defense argues the charges are barred by the NPA with Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the underlying sex abuse investigation. The motion argues the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement he entered into with the Southern District of Florida immunizes his potential co-conspirators, including Maxwell, for the offenses now charged.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Identified in the motion as Epstein's primary assistant from 2001-2004. The defense argues that 'Accuser-4' initially implicated Kellen, not Maxwell, in facilitating abuse during the Florida investigation.

persons.name: Accuser-4
persons.context: Also identified as Minor Victim-4. Her allegations from 2001-2004 form the basis for the new Counts Five and Six (sex trafficking) and the expanded timeframe in Counts One and Three. The defense argues her recent accusations against Maxwell contradict her 2007 statements.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, who signed the memorandum.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C., listed on the filing.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Haddon, Morgan & Foreman P.C., listed on the filing.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from the Law Offices of Bobbi C. Stemheim, listed on the filing.

persons.name: Elizabeth Nesbitt Kuyrkendall
persons.context: Lead case agent for the Florida Investigation. Her 2008 grand jury testimony summarizing her interview with Accuser-4 is cited extensively to show Accuser-4 did not initially implicate Maxwell.

persons.name: A. Marie Villafaña
persons.context: AUSA whose declaration is cited regarding Epstein's goal for a 'global resolution' via the NPA.

connections.description: The indictment alleges Maxwell conspired with Epstein to commit sex trafficking and Mann Act violations. The defense argues the NPA Epstein signed immunizes Maxwell as a 'potential co-conspirator'.
Both are presented as associates of Jeffrey Epstein. The defense contrasts Kellen's alleged role (as implicated by Accuser-4 in 2007) with Maxwell's alleged role (as implicated by Accuser-4 later).
Kellen is described as Epstein's 'primary assistant' during 2001-2004, who allegedly scheduled appointments and facilitated abuse according to initial victim statements.
Accuser-4 alleges Epstein sexually abused her during massages from 2001-2004 and paid her.
The S2 Indictment alleges Maxwell groomed, recruited, and facilitated the abuse of Accuser-4. The defense disputes this, citing Accuser-4's prior statements that did not mention Maxwell.
Everdell is one of the lead attorneys representing Maxwell in this criminal case.

events.title: Start of Alleged Abuse by Accuser-4
events.description: The period when Accuser-4 alleges the sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein began, forming the basis for the 2001-2004 timeframe in the S2 Indictment.

events.title: End of Alleged Abuse by Accuser-4
events.description: The period when Accuser-4 alleges the sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein ended.

events.title: Florida Investigation Interview of Accuser-4
events.description: The Palm Beach FBI and USAO-SDFL interviewed Accuser-4 as part of their investigation into Epstein. The defense states she implicated Sarah Kellen and Epstein, but not Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: SDFL Grand Jury Testimony
events.description: FBI Special Agent Elizabeth Nesbitt Kuyrkendall testified before a grand jury in the Southern District of Florida, summarizing Accuser-4's allegations and presenting evidence for a proposed 60-count indictment against Epstein and Sarah Kellen.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to Florida state charges (solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors) pursuant to the Non-Prosecution Agreement, which led to the abandonment of the proposed federal indictment.

events.title: Production of Prior Witness Statements
events.description: The government produced prior statements of non-testifying witnesses to the defense, including material related to Accuser-4's 2007-2008 statements.

keyFacts: The defense argues the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida immunizes 'any potential co-conspirators,' including Ghislaine Maxwell, for offenses from 2001-2007 that were investigated.

Counts Five and Six of the S2 Indictment, based on Accuser-4's allegations from 2001-2004, charge violations of 18 U.S.C. § 1591 (sex trafficking), which is one of the five offenses specifically enumerated in the NPA.

The motion claims Accuser-4, when interviewed in ~2007, implicated Sarah Kellen and Jeffrey Epstein in facilitating abuse but did not mention Ghislaine Maxwell, creating an inconsistency with her current allegations.

The defense contends that prosecuting Maxwell on Counts Five and Six constitutes double jeopardy because Epstein was already punished for those offenses via the NPA (state guilty plea, sex offender registration, victim settlements).
The motion requests the court to order the government to produce Accuser-4's prior statements to the FBI as exculpatory Brady material, arguing the omission of Maxwell is favorable to the defense.
